Hey, whatever it takes! :-)

But really, I realise that I'm a little late t=
o this particular
conversation, but it seems to me that testing even the si=
mple getters
and setters would fit well with the extremeness (is that a rea=
l word?)
of XP, that JUint came from.

I seem to recall that the Extreme lo=
gic, ran along the lines of:

if code reviews are good, then code review al=
l the time by programming
in pairs.

So, would we not say that if testing i=
s good (and I hope that we can all
agree on that one as members of a unit t=
est framework mailing list! :-)
then should we not say let's test everythin=
g? Even the simple setters
and getters are potential sources of errors.

I =
realise that unit tests are not a guarantee of 100% code coverage, but
leav=
ing out tests on even simple methods is even more guaranteed to not
give 10=
0% code coverage.

I'd also remind us all of some of the more impressive fa=
ilures in both
American and European space projects have been caused by tin=
y
insignificant errors. Example: A piece of 16bit oriented code being
asked=
 to hold a value outside of it's range. Example: the U.S. team
worked in im=
perial while the European team worked in metric. These are
silly little mis=
takes, but once your VERY expensive spacerocket is
thundering into the void=
, you can't bring it back and debug it.

I'll be testing my getters and set=
ters.

Just a thought. :-)

Simon
